title: 103_hr1817
content: The "Private Sector Whistleblowers' Protection Act of 1993" aims to protect individuals from reprisal for disclosing information related to violations of laws, mismanagement, waste of resources, endangerment of public health, and other abuses of authority by government agencies or their employees. SEC. 3. COVERAGE. This Act applies to Federal and State government agencies. SEC. 4. PROHIBITED REGULATORY PRACTICES. The Act defines "prohibited regulatory practice" as actions related to regulatory actions taken by Agency employees based on disclosures of violations or inconsistent application of laws, rules, regulations, policies, or internal standards. The Act defines "prohibited regulatory practice" as actions related to regulatory actions taken by Agency employees based on disclosures of violations or inconsistent application of laws, rules, regulations, policies, or internal standards. This includes arbitrary actions, mismanagement, waste of resources, endangerment of public health or safety, personal favoritism, and coercion for partisan political purposes by any agency or its employees. An action is considered to be influenced by the disclosure of information if it was a contributing factor to the decision. SEC. 5. PROHIBITED REGULATORY PRACTICE AS A DEFENSE TO AGENCY ACTION. In any administrative or judicial action, a person can assert a defense if the agency or its employees engaged in a prohibited regulatory practice. If proven, the person may need to comply with obligations but no penalties will be imposed. SEC. 6. ENFORCEMENT. SEC. 6. ENFORCEMENT. Any agency or employee engaging in a prohibited regulatory practice may face a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per practice. The President will establish procedures for enforcement. SEC. 7. CITIZEN SUITS. Any person harmed by a prohibited regulatory practice can sue the responsible party in district court. The court can issue injunctions, cancel penalties, fines, or settlements resulting from the practice. The court can order the issuance of permits or licenses that were denied due to regulatory practices, and can also award damages for harm caused, including property damage, loss of profits, costs incurred, loss in business value, and legal fees. The court can order the payment of punitive damages up to $25,000 for each prohibited regulatory practice, with each day of continuing practice considered a separate violation. The Special Counsel, established by section 1211 of title 5, United States Code, can investigate prohibited regulatory practices upon request. The Counsel has the same investigative powers for regulatory practices as for personnel practices under section 1212 of title 5, United States Code.
